export default function Pcr() { return (

Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR)

PCR is a laboratory technique used to amplify a specific segment of DNA, creating millions or even billions of copies from a tiny initial sample. This makes it possible to study DNA in detail, even if the starting material is extremely limited. PCR has become one of the most fundamental tools in molecular biology because of its speed, precision, and versatility.

Process

  • Denaturation: The double-stranded DNA is heated to separate it into two single strands.
  • Annealing: Short DNA sequences called primers bind to the specific regions of the DNA that need to be copied. These primers act like starting points for DNA synthesis.
  • Extension: A heat-stable DNA polymerase enzyme builds new DNA strands by adding nucleotides to the primers, effectively copying the target segment.

These steps are repeated for 20â€“40 cycles, doubling the amount of target DNA each time, resulting in exponential amplification.

Applications

PCR is widely used in diagnostics, forensics, and molecular biology experiments. For example, PCR tests for COVID-19 amplify viral RNA to detect even tiny amounts of the virus, enabling early and accurate diagnosis.

); }
